title: Isaiah's Sign of Judgment
shortSummary: Isaiah 20 records a prophetic sign acted out by Isaiah himself, symbolizing the coming humiliation and captivity of Egypt and Ethiopia by Assyria. This chapter highlights God's sovereignty over nations and His use of prophetic actions to warn His people of impending judgment. It serves as a vivid reminder of the futility of trusting in worldly powers rather than God.
timeline: c. 713 BC - During the reign of Sargon II of Assyria

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of God who acts out a symbolic sign by walking naked and barefoot to demonstrate the coming captivity of Egypt and Ethiopia.

keyCharacters.name: Sargon II
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who sent his commander Tartan to capture Ashdod, initiating the events described in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Tartan
keyCharacters.description: The Assyrian commander sent by King Sargon to attack Ashdod, marking the historical context of Isaiah's prophecy.

definitions.definition: A title for a high-ranking military commander in the Assyrian army.
A coarse, rough fabric worn as a sign of mourning, repentance, or humiliation.
A symbolic state representing shame, humiliation, and defeat in biblical prophecy.
In the Bible, often referring to the region south of Egypt, known as Cush, representing a powerful kingdom allied with Egypt.

outline.heading: Historical Context of Assyrian Campaign
outline.description: The chapter opens by situating the prophecy during the Assyrian military campaign against Ashdod, led by Tartan under King Sargon II, setting the stage for the prophetic sign.

outline.heading: Isaiah’s Prophetic Sign: Walking Naked and Barefoot
outline.description: God commands Isaiah to remove his sackcloth and shoes, walking naked and barefoot for three years as a visible sign of the coming humiliation of Egypt and Ethiopia.

outline.heading: The Meaning of the Sign: Captivity and Shame
outline.description: The prophecy explains that Assyria will lead away Egyptian and Ethiopian captives in shameful conditions, symbolizing their defeat and the failure of their alliances.

outline.heading: The Futility of Trusting in Egypt and Ethiopia
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a warning that those who flee to Egypt and Ethiopia for help will find no escape from Assyrian conquest, emphasizing reliance on God alone.

application: Trust in God rather than worldly powers or alliances, recognizing His sovereignty over nations and history.
Obediently follow God’s commands, even when they seem difficult or humiliating, as Isaiah did in this prophetic act.
Remember that God uses signs and warnings to call His people to repentance and faithfulness.
Be aware that pride in human strength or alliances can lead to shame and defeat; humility before God is essential.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said, Like as my servant Isaiah hath walked naked and barefoot three years for a sign and wonder upon Egypt and upon Ethiopia;
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the prophetic action Isaiah took as a divine sign symbolizing the coming judgment on Egypt and Ethiopia.

keyVerses.text: So shall the king of Assyria lead away the Egyptians prisoners, and the Ethiopians captives, young and old, naked and barefoot, even with their buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains the meaning of Isaiah’s sign, portraying the humiliation and captivity that Egypt and Ethiopia will suffer.

keyVerses.text: And the inhabitant of this isle shall say in that day, Behold, such is our expectation, whither we flee for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria: and how shall we escape?
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns of the futility of trusting in Egypt and Ethiopia for deliverance, urging reliance on God alone.
